content: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: New film explores “Don’t Ask” military policy FEBRUARY 27, 2009 Next week marks the 15th anniversary of the "Dont' Ask, Don't Tell" policy adopted by the military during the Clinton Administration. San Francisco filmmaker Johnny Symons visits St. Lawrence University as part of the “Out at the Movies” LGBT film festival Monday night. His new film, Ask Not, explores the policy that prevents openly gay men and women from serving in the military. The film has been shown in large cities around the country and Symons told Todd Moe he's eager for small town audiences to see it. >http://www.northcountrypublicradio.org/news/story/13075/new-film-explores-don-t-ask-military-policy Film web site ... >http://www.asknotfilm.com/ "Public" radio is known for their controversial, liberal viewpoints. Reckon the film maker takes an objective position, or....might there be an agenda here?
quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: New film explores “Don’t Ask” military policy FEBRUARY 27, 2009 Next week marks the 15th anniversary of the "Dont' Ask, Don't Tell" policy adopted by the military during the Clinton Administration. San Francisco filmmaker Johnny Symons visits St. Lawrence University as part of the “Out at the Movies” LGBT film festival Monday night. His new film, Ask Not, explores the policy that prevents openly gay men and women from serving in the military. The film has been shown in large cities around the country and Symons told Todd Moe he's eager for small town audiences to see it. >http://www.northcountrypublicradio.org/news/story/13075/new-film-explores-don-t-ask-military-policy Film web site ... >http://www.asknotfilm.com/
reply: "Public" radio is known for their controversial, liberal viewpoints. Reckon the film maker takes an objective position, or....might there be an agenda here?
title: New film explores “Don’t Ask” military policy

I can watch it via the computer Internet connection for a minimal monthly fee, so I may give it a try. I hope "Here" isn't like LOGO where most of the shows are directed at the younger generation and lately LOGO has been showing an overabundant selection of Lady movies ,,, no disrespect to the ladies here, but us gay guys are getting the short end of the stick on the movie selections (smile)...

content: quote: Originally posted by JimCrackCorn: I hope "Here" isn't like LOGO where most of the shows are directed at the younger generation and lately LOGO has been showing an overabundant selection of Lady movies ,,, no disrespect to the ladies here, but us gay guys are getting the short end of the stick on the movie selections (smile)... LOL, I understand your point. It does appear that LOGO has been favoring the *****s over the homo of late but I chalk that up to perhaps there is more film/stores available for the ladies. Nevertheless, it is great to have a venue where gay themed programming is available and not have to rely on the token gay in some of the network programs. The first gay character I recall (I am sure there were others) was on the infamous “Soap” sitcom of decades past. Then later there was Stephen on Dynasty and a sprinkling of others. When Will and Grace came along I believe that was the first gay themed show on a network and was groundbreaking and very successful. I recall a gay coffee shop in Houston had “Will and Grace Night” and the place was packed to watch on the big screen television. It became a Tuesday night social event. When LOGO first came out it was not an option here on COX Cable, so I called and told them I wanted it and sure enough it appeared in a week. According to a recent survey LOGO has been in the top 20% of the programs that has been subscribes to here in So Cal. Interesting.
quote: Originally posted by JimCrackCorn: I hope "Here" isn't like LOGO where most of the shows are directed at the younger generation and lately LOGO has been showing an overabundant selection of Lady movies ,,, no disrespect to the ladies here, but us gay guys are getting the short end of the stick on the movie selections (smile)...
reply: LOL, I understand your point. It does appear that LOGO has been favoring the *****s over the homo of late but I chalk that up to perhaps there is more film/stores available for the ladies. Nevertheless, it is great to have a venue where gay themed programming is available and not have to rely on the token gay in some of the network programs. The first gay character I recall (I am sure there were others) was on the infamous “Soap” sitcom of decades past. Then later there was Stephen on Dynasty and a sprinkling of others. When Will and Grace came along I believe that was the first gay themed show on a network and was groundbreaking and very successful. I recall a gay coffee shop in Houston had “Will and Grace Night” and the place was packed to watch on the big screen television. It became a Tuesday night social event. When LOGO first came out it was not an option here on COX Cable, so I called and told them I wanted it and sure enough it appeared in a week. According to a recent survey LOGO has been in the top 20% of the programs that has been subscribes to here in So Cal. Interesting.

content: My first 'exposure' to what I believe was 'gay' on TV was back in the early 1950s when I was a kid. Gorgeous George , the wrestler! Anyone remember him? Whatever became of him? Then nothing until the 1960s in some European 'art flicks' us college folks would intellectually go watch... whatever the heck they were about?

content: Gorgeous George: He grew his hair out so it was long, could be curled and pinned back with gold-plated bobby pins, and dyed it platinum blond. He wore elegant robes, dubbed himself "The Human Orchid" and was always escorted by one of his male ring valets (Geoffrey or Thomas Ross) who would spray his corner of the ring, as well as George's opponents, with disinfectant and perfume. He was the originator of using entrance music, and was always accompanied by his theme "Pomp And Circumstance"...which would again be used some 40 years later by Randy "Macho Man" Savage. Gorgeous George's ring entrances were legendary, and often took nearly as long as his matches. The effeminate grappler worked people into fits of laughter, curiosity, and outright rage with his pageantry and theatrics. "http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/georgebio.html He imitated a gay person in a comical way to attract large crowds and was highly successful at it.
reply: Gorgeous George: He grew his hair out so it was long, could be curled and pinned back with gold-plated bobby pins, and dyed it platinum blond. He wore elegant robes, dubbed himself "The Human Orchid" and was always escorted by one of his male ring valets (Geoffrey or Thomas Ross) who would spray his corner of the ring, as well as George's opponents, with disinfectant and perfume. He was the originator of using entrance music, and was always accompanied by his theme "Pomp And Circumstance"...which would again be used some 40 years later by Randy "Macho Man" Savage. Gorgeous George's ring entrances were legendary, and often took nearly as long as his matches. The effeminate grappler worked people into fits of laughter, curiosity, and outright rage with his pageantry and theatrics. "http://www.wrestlingmuseum.com/pages/bios/halloffame/georgebio.html He imitated a gay person in a comical way to attract large crowds and was highly successful at it.

content: I just came across this ... Doc on Closeted Politicians Premieres at Tribeca Outrage, a documentary by Kirby Dick that exposes closeted gay and lesbian politicians who actively campaign against gay rights, will have its world premiere at the 2009 Tribeca Film Festival. Released by Magnolia Pictures, Outrage is described in promotional materials as "a searing indictment of the hypocrisy of closeted politicians who actively campaign against the LGBT community they covertly belong to." Dick, 52, most recently directed This Film Is Not Yet Rated, about the Motion Picture Association of America’s rating system. His 2005 documentary Twist of Faith, about Catholic Church complicity in hiding sexual abuse by priests, was nominated for an Academy Award. Outrage is one of 12 selections in the high-profile World Documentary Feature Competition, announced yesterday along with selections in the Discovery and World Narrative competitions. The Tribeca Film Festival, now in its eighth year, will run from April 22 to May 3 in New York City. >URL=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74779.asp]http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74779.asp[/URL] This could turn out to be interesting.

Dick, 52, most recently directed This Film Is Not Yet Rated, about the Motion Picture Association of America’s rating system. Outrage is one of 12 selections in the high-profile World Documentary Feature Competition, announced yesterday along with selections in the Discovery and World Narrative competitions.
